In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.

I.    INTRODUCTION 
1.   The Government of Solomon Islands has requested the Asian Development Bank (ADB) 
to  provide  technical  assistance  (TA)  to  strengthen  its  country  safeguard  systems  (CSS) 
framework and implementation capacity in the transport sector.1  The government, development 
partners,  and  stakeholders  were  consulted  during  an  ADB  mission  in  June  2012.2 The 
government has agreed on the impact, outcome, outputs, implementation arrangements, cost, 
financing,  and  terms  of  reference  for  the  proposed  TA.  The  TA  design  and  monitoring 
framework is in Appendix 1.3 
 
II.    ISSUES 
2.  Solomon Islands is one of the largest Pacific developing member countries of ADB. The 
National Development Strategy, 2011–2020 emphasizes integrating environmental and social 
protection into projects.4 The National Transport Plan, 2011–2030 calls for (i) minimizing the 
environmental and social impacts of the transport network, (ii) ensuring that people are not 
unduly affected by transport projects, and (iii) developing and applying relevant laws to follow 
proper processes.5 The Ministry of Infrastructure Development (MID) is primarily responsible for 
infrastructure  development.  The  Ministry  of  Environment,  Climate  Change,  Disaster 
Management, and Meteorology (MECCDM) and the Ministry of Land, Housing, and Survey 
(MLHS) are responsible for managing environmental and land aspects. 
 
3.  ADB has assisted the government, particularly MID, in implementing transport projects 
financed  by  ADB  and  other  development  partners  by  enabling  projects’  adherence  to 
safeguard. 6  Safeguard  mechanisms  and  procedures  have  been  integrated  into  project 
management structures, and project staff are developing skills for implementing safeguards. For 
example, the Road Improvement (Sector) Project (footnote 6) included safeguard specialists, 
who trained national counterpart staff and assisted in implementing safeguard procedures. The 
Transport Sector Development Project (footnote 6) will further build capacity in MID to adhere to 
safeguards at the project level and consolidate the sector approach for project management 
through a centralized project implementation unit.   
 
                                                
1  CSS are a country’s legal and institutional framework, consisting of its implementing institutions and relevant laws, 
regulations, rules, and procedures that pertain to the policy areas of environmental and social safeguards. CSS 
and “safeguards” in this document pertain particularly to environment assessment and resettlement. 
2  Fact-finding  for  the  TA  was  undertaken  in  conjunction  with  the  review  mission  for  the  Transport  Sector 
Development Project (footnote 6) and the fact-finding mission for ADB. 2012. Report and Recommendation of the 
President to the Board of Directors: Proposed Loan and Grant to Solomon Islands for the Broadband for 
Development Project. Manila. 
3  The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 17 October 2012.  
4  Government of Solomon Islands. 2011. National Development Strategy, 2011−2020. Honiara. 
5  Government of Solomon Islands. 2010. National Transport Plan, 2011–2030. Honiara.

the President to the Board of Directors: Proposed Asian Development Fund Grant and Administration of Grants  to 
Solomon Islands for the Second Road Improvement (Sector) Project. Manila (Grants 0175, 0176, and 0177); ADB. 
2010. Report and Recommendation of the President to the Board of Directors: Proposed Grant and Administration 
of Technical Assistance Grant to Solomon Islands for the Transport Sector Development Project. Manila (Grant 
0243). 
.

2   
4.   The government has established the National Transport Fund to implement the National 
Transport Plan and has asked development partners to channel funds for transport projects 
through this mechanism using country systems.7 This is a step towards adopting a sector-wide 
approach  to  transport  and  presents  an  excellent  opportunity  for  the  government  and  its 
development  partners  to  harmonize  safeguards  and  other  matters  by  developing  common 
frameworks,  structures,  and  capacities  within  the  sector—consolidating  experiences  and 
capacities gained from projects.  
 
5.  However, there are several challenges to implementing a sector-wide approach reliant 
on country systems. The CSS framework does not currently address several aspects that the 
safeguard policies of development partners such as ADB, Japan International Cooperation 
Agency, and the World Bank consider essential.8 MID, MECCDM, and MLHS lack sufficient 
capacity and resources to effectively implement and monitor CSS.9 Staff members of these 
agencies have only limited experience in safeguard assessment, preparing safeguard plans, or 
implementing  or  monitoring  them.  Weak  institutional  capacity  on  CSS  presents  several 
challenges  to  implementing  safeguards  in  projects,  whether  funded  externally  or  by  the 
government. As safeguard requirements so far have been developed mainly in the management 
structures of externally funded projects, safeguard outcomes vary across projects. Overarching 
sector  guidelines  are  urgently  needed  to  achieve  a  consistent  approach  across  transport 
projects and strengthen sector institutions. 
 
6.  Land acquisition has commonly been problematic. The government has little experience 
with formal land acquisition and compensation in the transport sector.10 MID has emphasized 
that all future projects need to be developed by applying proper land acquisition procedures. 
This  process  is  new  to  many  government  staff,  so  they  need  capacity  building  on  land 
acquisition and compensation processes and on the differences and similarities between CSS 
and development partners’ safeguard requirements. There are challenges in environmental 
safeguards as well. These include inadequate capacity to assess, plan, implement, and monitor 
environmental requirements in compliance with the CSS framework and development partners’ 
safeguard policies.  
 
7.  The government plans to meet these challenges by strengthening the CSS framework 
and building capacity in key ministries. It has requested ADB to provide the TA to review CSS, 
assess institutional capacity, prepare an action plan, and implement training and capacity-
building initiatives. The government has chosen transport as the first sector for strengthening 
CSS. Projects in other sectors such as energy and mining will benefit from the strengthened 
CSS framework and the improved implementation capacity of MID, MECCDM, and MLHS, 
which are responsible for all infrastructure and related safeguards. 
 
                                                
7  The National Transport Fund currently covers most transport projects, but some projects still operate outside of it.    
8  Gaps have been identified in information disclosure, grievance redress, compensation to non-titleholders, restoring 
the livelihoods of affected people, and compliance monitoring. A detailed analysis comparing the CSS framework 
with international standards is proposed under the TA. 
9  The Environment and Conservation Division of MECCDM has a total staff of 12, but only 6 are available to review 
environmental assessments or monitor impacts. MID currently has no safeguards staff but is expected under 
provisions of the Transport Sector Development Project to create two new safeguard staff positions. MLHS has 
about 15 staff, but most have received no safeguards training and are not involved in MID projects.  
10  The process adopted in the past for obtaining land was through an informal memorandum of understanding, which 
required agreements from customary landowners and communities to develop a project without compensation to 
affected individuals. This has not worked well for various reasons: some groups have not agreed or wanted to 
renegotiate previous agreements; MID and its contractors have been inundated with requests for in-kind works 
beyond initial agreements; and individuals within communities have sought cash compensation.

3 
III.     THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
8.  The impact of the TA will be transport projects implemented in an environmentally and 
socially responsible manner. This will be measured by the percentage of transport projects 
adopting the improved environmental and social safeguard systems. 
 
9.  The  outcome  of  the  TA  will  be  the  improved  CSS  framework  and  implementation 
capacity on environmental and social safeguards in the transport sector. This will be measured 
by  (i)  the  number  of  staff  of  MID,  MECCDM,  MLHS,  and  other  agencies  trained  on 
environmental and social safeguards and (ii) the availability to transport projects of  sector 
guidelines for environmental assessment and for land acquisition and resettlement. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
10.  The TA will comprise the following four outputs and key activities to achieve the outcome.  
 
11.  Output 1: Country safeguard systems review. The CSS review will include (i) analysis 
comparing  Solomon  Islands’  CSS  framework  with  international  best  practices,  and  (ii) 
recommendations to enhance CSS’ consistency with them. An inventory of laws, decrees, 
regulations,  and  other  mandates  related  to  environmental  and  social  safeguards  will  be 
compiled with a focus on transport. The laws in other sectors will be reviewed if they directly 
relate to the objective of the TA. Aspirational policy statements, such as those found in the 
Constitution or sector policies, will be inventoried for their potential alignment with international 
best  practices.  Legal  instruments  in  draft  form  such  as  bills  and  draft  regulations  will  be 
identified as potential measures for CSS strengthening. The comparative analysis of Solomon 
Islands’  CSS  framework  with  international  best  practices  on  environmental  and  social 
safeguards will use the methodology for strengthening CSS set out in ADB’s guidance note for 
review of CSS. The analysis will reference ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement (2009) as a 
benchmark.  
 
12.  Output 2: Institutional capacity assessment. The TA will assess the ability of MID, 
MECCDM,  and  MLHS  to  implement  CSS  by  assessing  their (i)  capacity  in  terms  of their 
responsibilities, resources and tools; (ii) existing implementation practices and procedures; and 
(iii) performance on environmental and social safeguards. This component will include a training 
needs assessment to determine recommendations and activities to be included in outputs 3 and 
4. Selected case studies will highlight what is being done in transport projects and what should 
be  done  to  improve  implementation  capacity.  This  component  will  be  designed  without 
duplicating support provided under other projects. 
 
13.  Workshops will be organized to discuss draft reports on the CSS review (output 1) and 
the institutional capacity assessment (output 2). The objective is to identify key issues and reach 
consensus on recommended actions among government agencies, development partners, civil 
society organizations, and other stakeholders. The final reports on the CSS review and the 
capacity  assessment  will  incorporate  comments  received  during  the  workshop  and  other 
consultations. 
 
14.  Output 3: Action plan for strengthening country safeguard systems framework 
and implementation capacity. A draft action plan will be prepared based on outputs 1 and 2 
articulating a set of interventions to improve the CSS framework and develop the capacity of

4   
MID, MECCDM, MLHS, and other agencies to implement environmental and social safeguards 
in the transport sector. The draft action plan will be discussed with stakeholders, including 
government  agencies,  development  partners,  and  civil  society  organizations.  Consultation 
workshops in the form of facilitated discussions will arrive at an action plan by consensus. 
Development partners will be invited to consultation workshops to provide their views and clarify 
how they can support the action plan. The final action plan will take into account the results of 
stakeholder consultations and be submitted to the government for endorsement. Some priority 
capacity-building activities identified in the action plan (e.g., training and developing guidelines) 
will be implemented under the TA as output 4. Other activities will be implemented subsequently 
by the government or other projects.   
 
15.  Output 4: Training and capacity building initiatives. Based on the findings of the 
training needs assessment and priorities in the action plan (output 3), the TA will conduct a 
series of institutional strengthening activities to build the capacity of MID, MLHS, MECCDM, 
other ministries, and stakeholders to implement CSS. The TA will (i) raise government agencies’ 
and  stakeholders’  awareness  of  CSS  and  international  safeguard  standards;  (ii)  conduct 
workshops, on-the-job training linked with existing projects, and intensive training courses on 
safeguards; (iii) develop transport sector guidelines for environmental assessment and for land 
acquisition and resettlement; and (iv) pursue other activities prioritized in the action plan. The 
TA  will  explore  opportunities  and  coordinate  with  development  partners  to share  Solomon 
Islands’ experience on CSS strengthening with other countries in the region. A recommendation 
to share knowledge on CSS nationally and regionally will be included in the action plan. 
 
16.  The  TA  outputs  will  be  published  on  the  ADB  website  and  will  be  provided  to 
government agencies and other stakeholders for public dissemination. This will showcase TA 
outputs  and  encourage  agencies  in  Solomon  Islands  and  abroad  to  share  lessons  and 
experiences on CSS strengthening.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
17.  The TA is estimated to cost $600,000 which will be financed on a grant basis by the 
Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction and administered by ADB. The government will provide 
counterpart support in the form of office accommodation, counterpart staff and other in-kind 
contributions. The cost estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
18.  The TA will be implemented over 18 months, from 1 April 2013 to 30 September 2014. 
 
19.  MID will be the executing agency and will be responsible for overseeing and monitoring 
TA implementation. It has implemented several transport projects financed by ADB and other 
development partners and has a satisfactory track record in project implementation. MECCDM, 
MLHS, and other agencies will actively participate in implementing the TA. A working group will 
be established to coordinate TA activities. It will be chaired by the MID permanent secretary, or 
his  or  her  representative,  and  will  comprise  representatives  of  MECCDM,  MLHS,  other 
ministries, development partners, and stakeholders. The detailed terms of reference of the 
working group will be finalized during the inception mission. The TA consultants will provide 
necessary support to the working group. 
 
20.  The  TA  will  require  a  total  of  40  person-months  of  consulting  services.  Three 
international consultants providing a total of 15 person-months and two national consultants

5 
providing a total of 25 person-months will form the TA team. The international consultants will 
lead TA activities in their respective safeguard areas of expertise: environment safeguards, 
resettlement safeguards, and legal aspects. National consultants will assist in assessing CSS, 
conducting case studies in the transport sector, planning activities, and implementing the TA. 
The international environmental safeguard specialist will be the TA team leader, coordinating TA 
activities and serving as the secretary to the working group. The national safeguard specialist 
will be the acting secretary of the working group when the team leader is not present. ADB will 
recruit the consultants in accordance with its Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as 
amended from time to time). A consulting firm will be selected using the simplified technical 
proposal through the quality- and cost-based selection method with a quality–cost ratio of 90:10 
because of the complexity of the assignment. The terms of reference for the consultants are in 
Appendix  3.  Disbursements  will  conform  to  ADB’s  Technical  Assistance  Disbursement 
Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time). Any procurement of equipment will follow 
ADB Procurement Guidelines (2010, as amended from time to time). 
 
21.   The consultants will prepare the following reports on all activities and outputs under the 
TA: (i) an inception report within 4 weeks of the start of the TA consisting of a work program, 
methodology, and milestones; (ii) a semiannual progress report by the end of the 6th month of 
the TA, including outputs on the CSS review and the institutional capacity assessment; (iii) an 
annual progress report by the end of the 12th month, including outputs on the action plan for 
strengthening CSS and the guidelines on environment assessment, and land acquisition and 
resettlement; (iv) a draft final report by the end of the 17th month, including training and 
capacity-building outputs; and (v) a final report within 1 month after receiving the comments on 
the draft final report from the government and ADB. The consultants will submit two copies of 
each report to ADB and four copies to the government. The TA team leader will coordinate TA 
activities and consolidate TA outputs.  
 
22.   TA activities will be closely monitored and feedback sought from the government and 
stakeholders  on  TA  performance.  The  draft  TA  outputs  will  be  discussed  or  shared  with 
government  agencies,  development  partners,  and  other  stakeholders.  The  TA  will  widely 
disseminate  information  for  public  awareness  and  consultation  at  various  stages  through 
workshops, seminars, and meetings. A TA completion report will be prepared at the end of the 
TA. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
 
23.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved ADB 
administering technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $600,000 to the Government 
of Solomon Islands to be financed on a grant basis by the Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction for 
Strengthening Country Safeguard Systems in the Transport Sector, and hereby reports this 
action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  Three international consultants providing a total of 15 person-months and two national 
consultants providing a total of 25 person-months will be recruited through a firm to be selected 
by quality- and cost-based selection. The international consultants will be an environmental 
safeguard specialist and team leader, a resettlement safeguard specialist, and a legal specialist. 
National consultants will be a full-time safeguard specialist and a part-time legal specialist. 
 
A.   Environmental  Safeguard  Specialist  and  Team  Leader  (international,  6  person-
months) 
 
2.  The consultant will have a degree in an environmental subject; substantial expertise in 
drafting policies, procedures, and plans and implementing safeguards policies; and exposure to 
international best practice and country systems in Asia and the Pacific. 
 
3.  Environmental country safeguard systems review, capacity assessment, action 
plan,  and  training  and  capacity-building  initiatives.  The  consultant  will  undertake  an 
environmental CSS review and institutional capacity assessment following ADB’s guidance note 
for  review  of  country  safeguards  systems.  The  consultant  will  prepare  an  action  plan  for 
capacity  development  and  implement  selected  training  and  capacity-building  initiatives, 
including developing sector guidelines on environmental assessment, to implement CSS in the 
transport sector. The consultant will perform the following tasks: 
(i)  Coordinate with the legal specialist on the legal review and analysis of relevant 
environmental policies, laws, regulations, and other relevant documents. 
(ii)  Undertake  the  assessment  of  MID,  MECCDM,  and  MLHS  implementation 
capacity  on  environmental  aspects,  including  assessing  their  (a)  capacity  in 
terms of their responsibilities, resources, and tools; (b) implementation practice 
and procedures for environmental assessment; and (c) performance in delivering 
desired outputs and outcome. Undertake selected case studies to highlight what 
is being done and what should be done to improve implementation capacity. 
Update baseline data for the TA’s impact and outcome indicators. 
(iii)  Prepare recommendations for an action plan for strengthening environmental 
safeguards. The plan will consist of specific interventions for  developing the 
capacity of organizations to implement the environmental safeguards.  
(iv)  Prepare a draft report on the environmental CSS review and a draft action plan 
for presentation at the stakeholder workshop.  
(v)  Prepare a final report on environmental CSS review and an action plan after 
review by the government, ADB, and other stakeholders.  
(vi)  Implement priority capacity-building initiatives agreed with the government such 
as  training,  and  develop  sector  guidelines  on  environmental  assessment  for 
transport projects.  
 
4.  Guidance to national consultants. The consultant will perform the following tasks: 
(i)  Guide  the  national  consultants’  compilation  of  basic  information,  including 
existing policy, legislative, institutional, and budgetary frameworks for capacity 
assessment and action planning on environmental safeguards. 
(ii)  Guide the national consultants’ implementation of TA activities. 
(iii)  Manage national consultants’ activities and inputs.

10  Appendix 3 
 
 
 
5.  Coordination, liaison, and advice. The consultant will  perform the following tasks: 
(i)  Coordinate  with  ADB  staff,  development  partners,  participating  government 
agencies, and other stakeholders for the implementation of TA activities. 
(ii)  Act  as  a  resource  person  for  ADB  and  the  government  on  environmental 
safeguards. 
(iii)  Liaise with other international and national specialists. 
 
6.  Consultation and dissemination. The consultant will perform the following tasks: 
(i)  Undertake  meaningful  consultations  with  government  agencies,  development 
partners, civil society, and other stakeholders. Organize stakeholder workshops, 
including national consultative workshops in Honiara and regional workshops in 
regional centers. Organize meetings of focus groups, including nongovernment 
organizations, people affected by projects, and project implementation agencies. 
Prepare  and  circulate  consultative  draft  documents  in  English  and  local 
languages to facilitate informed discussion. 
(ii)  Actively participate in and make presentations at workshops and seminars as 
part of dissemination activities.  
 
7.  Team leadership. The consultant will perform the following tasks: 
(i)  Act as TA team leader and coordinate TA activities. 
(ii)  Draft  consolidated  reports  on  all  outputs  and  finalize  them  incorporating 
comments from ADB, the government, and other stakeholders.  
(iii)  Submit an inception report, semiannual and annual progress reports, a draft final 
report, and a final report. 
(iv)  Act as the secretary of the working group and facilitate effective communication 
between the government and TA consultants. 
 
B.  Resettlement Safeguard Specialist (international, 6 person-months) 
 
8.  The consultant will have a degree in social science; substantial expertise in drafting 
policies,  procedures,  and  plans  and  implementing  safeguards  policies;  and  exposure  to 
international best practices and country systems.  
 
9.  Country  safeguard  systems  review,  capacity  assessment,  action  plan,  and 
capacity building initiatives. The consultant will be primarily responsible for undertaking the 
CSS review and capacity assessment on social safeguards following ADB’s guidance note for 
review of country safeguards systems, preparing an action plan for capacity building, and 
implementing capacity-building initiatives on CSS in the transport sector, including developing 
sector guidelines on land acquisition and resettlement. The tasks include the following: 
(i)  Coordinate with the legal specialist on the legal review and analysis for CSS 
strengthening on land acquisition and resettlement safeguards. 
(ii)  Assess the implementation capacity of MID, MECCDM, and MLHS regarding 
land acquisition and resettlement, including their (a) capacity in terms of their 
responsibilities, resources, and tools; (b) implementation practice and procedures 
for  land  acquisition  and  resettlement;  and  (c)  performance  with  respect  to 
delivering desired outputs and achieving the desired outcome of resettlement 
safeguards. Undertake selected case studies to highlight what is being done and 
what should be done to improve implementation capacity. Update baseline data 
for the TA’s impact and outcome indicators

Appendix 3  11 
(iii)  Prepare  an  action  plan  to  strengthen  the  legal  framework  and  develop  the 
capacity of MID, MECCDM, and MLHS on land acquisition and resettlement 
safeguards.  
(iv)  Coordinate with the environmental safeguard specialist and team leader, and 
with the legal specialist, to develop and finalize the action plan with the working 
group. Facilitate meetings of the working group to discuss key issues.  
(v)  Coordinate with the environmental safeguard specialist and team leader, and 
with the legal specialist, to prepare a draft report on the CSS review, capacity 
assessment, and action plan for presentation at a stakeholder workshop. After 
review by the government, ADB, and other stakeholders, prepare final reports on 
them.  
(vi)  Implement priority capacity-building initiatives agreed with the government such 
as training. Develop the sector guidelines on land acquisition and resettlement. 
 
10.  Guidance to national safeguards consultant. The consultant will perform the following 
tasks: 
(i)  Guide  the  national  consultant’s  compilation  of  basic  information,  including 
existing  policy,  legislative,  institutional,  and  budgetary  frameworks  for  land 
acquisition and resettlement. 
(ii)  Guide the national consultant’s implementation of TA activities.  
(iii)  Manage the national consultant’s activities and inputs. 
 
11.  Coordination, liaison, and advice. The consultant will perform the following tasks: 
(i)  Coordinate  with  ADB  staff,  development  partners,  participating  government 
agencies,  and  other  stakeholders to  implement TA  activities  on resettlement 
safeguards. 
(ii)  Coordinate  with  the  government’s  working  group  and  facilitate  effective 
communication between the government and TA consultants. 
(iii)  Act  as  a  resource  person  for  ADB  and  the  government  on  resettlement 
safeguards. 
(iv)  Liaise with other international and national specialists. 
 
12.  Consultation and dissemination. The consultant will perform the following tasks: 
(i)  Undertake  meaningful  consultations  with  government  agencies,  development 
partners, civil society, and other stakeholders. Organize stakeholder workshops, 
including national consultative workshops in Honiara and regional workshops at 
regional  centers.  Organize  meetings  among  focus  groups,  including 
nongovernment  organizations,  people  affected  by  projects,  and  project 
implementation agencies. Prepare and circulate consultative draft documents in 
English and local languages to facilitate informed discussion. 
(ii)  Actively participate in and make presentations at workshops and seminars as 
part of dissemination activities. 
 
C.  Legal Specialist (international, 3 person-months)  
 
13.  The consultant will have a degree in law and substantial expertise in drafting policies, 
procedures,  and  plans;  good  understanding  of  safeguards  policies;  and  exposure  to 
international best practices and country systems.  
 
14.  Legal  analysis  to  strengthen  country  safeguard  system. The consultant will be 
primarily  responsible  for  preparing  the  legal  analysis  and  recommending  measures  to

12  Appendix 3 
 
 
strengthen the CSS on environmental and resettlement safeguards in accordance with ADB’s 
guidance note for review of country safeguard systems. Tasks include the following: 
(i)  Compile an inventory of (a) laws, decrees, regulations, administrative orders, and 
other  mandates  related  to  environmental  and  resettlement  safeguards;  (b) 
aspirational  policy  statements,  such  as  those  found  in  the  Constitution, 
framework, or sector policies for their potential correspondence to international 
best practices; and (c) legal instruments in draft form such as bills and draft 
regulations as potential measures for CSS strengthening. Complete the inventory 
after consultations with Solomon Islands legal experts. 
(ii)  Prepare a thorough and objective legal analysis using ADB Safeguard Policy 
Statement (2009) objectives, scope, and policy principles as benchmarks for 
Solomon  Island  legal  instruments  related  to  environmental  and  resettlement 
safeguards.  The  legal  analysis  will  (a)  develop  a  matrix  arranging  relevant 
safeguard elements, (b) summarize corresponding provisions in the CSS legal 
framework,  (c)  characterize  the  extent  of  equivalence  with  international  best 
practices,  and  (d)  identify  measures  to  make  CSS  more  consistent  with 
international best practices.  
(iii)  Recommend measures to strengthen the legal framework for environmental and 
resettlement safeguards.  
(iv)  Prepare a draft report on the legal analysis including recommendations.  
(v)  Organize workshops to discuss the draft report on legal analysis.  
(vi)  Prepare a final report on legal analysis and recommendations after review by the 
government, ADB, and other stakeholders.  
(vii)  Coordinate with the environmental safeguard specialist and team leader, and 
with the resettlement specialist, to implement the TA with the working group.  
 
15.  Guidance to the national legal consultant. The consultant will perform the following 
tasks: 
(i)  Guide the national consultant’s compilation of basic information on legal aspects. 
(ii)  Guide the national consultant’s implementation of TA activities.  
(iii)  Manage the national consultant’s activities and inputs. 
 
16.  Coordination, liaison, and advice. The consultant will perform the following tasks:  
(i)  Coordinate with ADB staff, development partners, participating government 
agencies, and other stakeholders to implement activities. 
(ii)  Liaise with development partners and government agencies to promote 
coordination and consistency on the legal analysis. 
(iii)  Liaise with other specialists to coordinate TA activities and reports. 
(iv)  Coordinate with the government’s working group and facilitate effective 
communication between the government and TA consultants. 
   
17.  Consultation and dissemination. The consultant will perform the following tasks: 
(i)  Undertake necessary consultations to inform stakeholders and solicit their input 
to the legal analysis. 
(ii)  Organize  and  make  presentations  in  workshops  and  seminars  as  part  of 
dissemination activities.

Appendix 3  13 
D.  National Safeguard Specialist (national, 18 person-months) 
 
18.  The  specialist  should  have  a  degree  in  a  social  or  environmental  subject  and  an 
understanding of environmental and social safeguards in Solomon Islands. Experience working 
with multilateral or bilateral development agencies will be an advantage.  
 
19.  The  national  specialist  will  support  the  international  environment  and  resettlement 
safeguard specialists in implementing the TA. In the absence of the international specialists, the 
national  specialist  will  coordinate  TA  activities  nationally  including  serving  as  the  acting 
secretary of the working group. Detailed tasks include the following:  
(i)  Assist  the  international  safeguard  specialists  in  collecting,  reviewing,  and 
analyzing relevant information for (a) assessing CSS and institutional capacity on 
environmental and resettlement safeguards, (b) preparing an action plan, and (c) 
implementing capacity-building initiatives prioritized in the action plan. 
(ii)  Provide support to the working group.  
(iii)  Assist in organizing workshops and meetings to consult with stakeholders and 
solicit their views and inputs.  
(iv)  Prepare necessary materials in local language(s) for information dissemination 
and consultation related to TA activities. 
(v)  Provide inputs into the TA reports. 
(vi)  Facilitate in-country dissemination and liaison activities.  
(vii)  Perform tasks assigned by ADB staff and international consultants.  
 
E.  National Legal Specialist (national, 7 person-months) 
 
20.  The specialist should have a degree in law; good understanding of legal systems in 
Solomon  Islands,  preferably  on  environmental  and  resettlement  aspects;  and  experience 
working with multilateral or bilateral development agencies.  
 
21.  The  specialist  will  provide  country-specific  inputs  to  the  legal  analysis  of  Solomon 
Island’s CSS, preparation of an action plan, and implementation of capacity building on CSS in 
the transport sector. More specifically, the specialist will perform the following tasks:  
(i)  Assist in compiling the legal inventory by collecting all legal information and 
instruments, including laws, decrees, regulations, administrative orders, policies, 
and other mandates, on environmental and resettlement safeguards.  
(ii)  Assist in the legal analysis of CSS based on this information.  
(iii)  Provide inputs into reports on the legal analysis and recommendations on CSS.  
(iv)  Work  with  the  international  legal  specialist  to  prepare  an  action  plan  for 
strengthening the legal and regulatory framework for Solomon Island’s CSS in 
the transport sector. 
(v)  Facilitate in-country consultation and information dissemination, particularly on 
legal  aspects,  including  consultation  with  development  partners,  government 
agencies, and other stakeholders.  
(vi)  Assist in organizing consultation workshops to discuss draft reports. 
(vii)  Assist in implementing capacity-building initiatives and other TA activities. 
(viii)  Provide other country-specific inputs to the TA as needed.
